subject: Re: [junit] Bumblebee 0.2, feedback requested
msgSnippet: Hi David, I hope you ll enjoy it. Drop me a line if you need any help. I d also like to know what disturbs and what you miss. If you would have some feedback

Hi David,

I hope you'll enjoy it. Drop me a line if you need any help. I'd=
 also
like to know what disturbs and what you miss.

If you would have some=
 feedback on the JUnit integration in the
implementation that would be grea=
t, too. :-)

Cheers
Daniel

On Nov 19, 2007 8:03 PM, David Saff <saff@mit.e=
du> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Daniel,
>
>  I've just given the documentation a l=
ook. I'm looking forward to
>  giving it a spin--I had a similar thought a =
month or two ago, and I'm
>  glad to see you already did the hard work!
>
>=
  David
>
>
>
>  On Nov 13, 2007 2:45 AM, Daniel Brolund <daniel.brolund@gm=
ail.com> wrote:
>  > Hi Nat,
>  > I see that my approach is very similar to=
 yours, and the limited
>  > response I've gotten so far is pretty much the=
 same: you better see
>  > how well the tests describe the code!
>  >
>  > =
One other interesting effect is that after a while I start to get
>  > docu=
mentation-driven tests, meaning that I put myself in the end users
>  > pos=
ition, write the documentation for the feature I'm about to
>  > implement =
(as a good method name and a comment in the test method),
>  > write the te=
st and asserts for it, and then implement the feature.
>  > After having ru=
n the tests the documentation is ready to be reviewed,
>  > it takes about =
3 secs on my computer (and approx 1 sec is starting up
>  > JRuby).
>  >
> =
 > Right now it is a bit awkward since I write tests for the
>  > documenta=
tion features which are mainly comments. I am, however, using
>  > document=
ation asserts (in the comments) that actually shows up in the
>  > JUnit re=
port in Eclipse, so I get pretty good feedback. One way of
>  > putting it =
is that I'm test-driving the documentation while I'm
>  > documentation-dri=
ving the tests... :-)
>  >
>  > I'm still not sure exactly the best place t=
o use Bumblebee (or
>  > Protest), but I know that for API-documentation it=
 will definitely be
>  > a good thing.
>  > With TDDoc I experimented with =
Abbot tests ("GUI-clicking") where I
>  > complemented the comments with im=
ages by pulling bitmaps from the
>  > Swing frames, and then generating Jav=
aHelp files (using docbook), and
>  > it actually worked (with a few minor =
flaws). It should be possible to
>  > do the same thing with Bumblebee. I d=
on't want to start a new thread
>  > on whether GUI-clicking is a good way =
to test your application (I
>  > generally think it is not), but with autom=
atically generated JavaHelp
>  > in the equation the balance might change a=
 bit for some people.
>  >
>  > Cheers
>  > Daniel, still wanting more feed=
back
>  >
>  >
>  >
>  > On Nov 12, 2007 10:18 PM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@gma=
il.com> wrote:
>  > >
>  > >
>  > >
>  > >
>  > >
>  > >
>  > > Very intere=
sting! I like the idea of generating useful documentation
> from
>  > > tes=
t code. I wrote a tool & test framework with similar goals for
> Python
>  =
> > called Protest (http://xspecs.sf.net/protest.html).
>  > >
>  > > One i=
nteresting effect I found when using Protest is that the generated
>  > > d=
ocumentation was enough of a different perspective on the test code
> that
=
>  > > just skim-reading it gave really fast feedback on whether the tests
=
> acted
>  > > as
>  > > a clear description of the tested code's behaviour=
.
>  > >
>  > > --Nat
>  > >
>  > >
>  > >
>  > > On 11/11/2007, Daniel Bro=
lund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
>  > > >
>  > > > Hi all,
>  > > > I=
 would really appreciate some feedback on a small framework I'm
>  > > > wr=
iting for JUnit 4.4.
>  > > >
>  > > > I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose=
 of it is to use comments and the
>  > > > structures in the test-suites/ca=
ses/methods to create
> "human-readable"
>  > > > documentation. It is espe=
cially well suited for writing snippet-heavy
>  > > > documentation.
>  > >=
 >
>  > > > In short, Bumblebee gets events from the execution of the tests=

>  > > > (suites/classes/methods) and then parses the classes and methods =
for
>  > > > specific comments to include.
>  > > >
>  > > > By default it =
adds the de-camelcased names of the
> suites/cases/methods
>  > > > as head=
ings (a la agile dox), and the contained comments becomes the
>  > > > para=
graphs.
>  > > >
>  > > > The comments are actually handled as Ruby-strings=
 that get executed
> in
>  > > > a Bumblebee execution context before being=
 added to the output. The
>  > > > execution context is
>  > > > a kind of =
DSL for including code-snippets and other things needed,
> and
>  > > > one=
 of the core ideas of Bumblebee is that you should be able to
>  > > > exte=
nd that functionality easily.
>  > > >
>  > > > More detailed information a=
bout Bumblebee can be found at:
>  > > >
>  > > > http://www.agical.com/bum=
blebee/bumblebee_doc.html
>  > > >
>  > > > which is of course generated wi=
th Bumblebee. :-)
>  > > >
>  > > > The concept of Bumblebee is the same as=
 for TDDoc, which me and
> Joakim
>  > > > Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as =
an add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
>  > > > TDDoc became a bit of a dead-e=
nd technically, and Joakim and I
> thought
>  > > > it would be a good idea=
 to start fresh. I happened to have the time
> at
>  > > > the time and I s=
tarted it up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
>  > > > your credits=
 to Joakim!
>  > > >
>  > > > This is an early release, and I will be very =
happy for any feedback I
>  > > > can get to improve it.
>  > > >
>  > > > =
Cheers
>  > > > Daniel Brolund
>  > > >
>  > > > __________________________=
